title: Antihypertensives and Wet AMD: What’s the Risk?
author: Stefani Kim

content: High blood pressure, also called hypertension, can cause a multitude of serious health issues if left untreated. These include heart attack , stroke , kidney failure, and heart failure as well as vision problems. High blood pressure is a risk factor for age-related macular degeneration (AMD), an eye disease that can cause vision loss.

Doctors often initially recommend patients modify lifestyle factors in order to reduce blood pressure, focusing on healthy eating and regular exercise. Antihypertensive drugs can also be prescribed for patients whose blood pressure remains stubbornly high. However, there has been some research that suggests a connection between some classes of blood pressure medicines and AMD.

It can be difficult to draw definite conclusions from the studies showing a connection between some antihypertensives and wet AMD, the more serious form of AMD that can cause sudden vision loss, according to Vaidehi Dedania, MD, a retinal ophthalmologist and surgeon at NYU Langone Health. This is because the studies tend to encompass a diverse group of individuals with varying health issues.

content: “These studies are already looking at patients at high risk of hypertension. You tend to see hypertension more in 60-year-olds and not in 20-year-olds, and more in patients, for example, who are obese, and more in patients who are smoking, patients who already have all these other risk factors,” she said. “Some of these studies control for that, but it’s really hard to control for that completely.”

Patients should balance risk of the serious health issues with uncontrolled hypertension, for which there is strong evidence, against the less substantiated evidence around anti-hypertensives, said Dedania.

“If a patient were to ask me about it and say, ‘Hey, listen, I read this article that says my blood pressure medicine is associated with [AMD],’ I would tell them that it’s life over the eye,” said Dedania. “I counsel them, ‘It’s not that you can’t see, it’s that there is some report that there may be a very marginal, slim association between these, whereas we know that stopping your medicine is going to compromise your life significantly and your health.’”

content: Hypertension, much like smoking and diabetes, may also damage the blood vessels carrying oxygen to the retina and whisking away waste products, said Christina Weng, MD, a retina specialist, surgeon, and professor at the Baylor College of Medicine. Though there are studies suggesting a connection between some antihypertensives and AMD, she said, it’s difficult to parse which factor is more influential to retinal damage.

“I would say it’s inconclusive thus far because we also know that high blood pressure can increase the role of AMD, so it’s like you’re between a rock and a hard place,” said Weng. “Do you choose [high] blood pressure or do you choose the blood pressure drugs?”

meta_description: High blood pressure and the drugs that treat it may connect to AMD. Doctors explain the risks.
